Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Core-shell structure where ZnO is the core and FeNi-MOF is the shell, with 3D nanosized region, bending irregularities, and interconnected mesopores formed by FeNi-MOF nano-clusters.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion, passes through tiny pores of FeNi-MOF shell; enhanced adsorption due to nano-confinement effect.

Other Information.Test Conditions: In solutions containing natural organic matter (NOM) and inorganic ions; also in tap water, surface water, and secondary effluent from sewage treatment plants.
Other Information.Additional Info: Adsorption capacity maintained high in complex water matrices due to selective passage.

Guest Molecules.Molecular Size: Much larger than TC (molecular weight: few hundred to few hundred thousand Daltons)
Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion, excluded by the pores of the FeNi-MOF shell due to larger molecular size.

Other Information.Test Conditions: In solutions containing tetracycline and inorganic ions.
Other Information.Additional Info: Presence of NOM did not significantly interfere with tetracycline degradation, indicating its exclusion.

Sieving Mechanism: Molecular sieving based on size exclusion by the FeNi-MOF shell combined with nano-confinement effects for selective enrichment of smaller pollutants like tetracycline.

Experimental Validation.Method: Adsorption experiments in solutions containing NOM and inorganic ions; catalytic degradation experiments in real water matrices.
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Adsorption capacity of TC on FeNi-MOF and ZCM2 showed no significant decrease in presence of NOM and inorganic ions (unlike ZnO and ZnO/BC). TC degradation efficiencies > 88% in tap water, surface water, and secondary effluent.

Other Information.Additional Info: Core-shell nanoreactor structure with ZnO core and FeNi-MOF shell. The FeNi-MOF shell mitigates metal ion leaching. ROS generation in limited space within the shell provides strong driving force for TC oxidation. The composite exhibits slight hydrophobicity (contact angle: 118.895°).
